newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU monetary committee discusses Markka ERM entry.
newsitem.headline: EU monetary committee discusses Markka ERM entry.

text.p: The European Union's monetary committee met on Saturday to discuss the entry of the Finnish markka into the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, EU diplomats said on Saturday.
"The meeting began shortly after 2 p.m (1200 gmt)," one diplomat told Reuters.
EU monetary sources said the meeting could be very short, given expected broad support for the Finnish currency's entry.

The markka has been floating freely since September 8, 1992. It was briefly linked unilaterally to the European currency unit (Ecu) between June and November 1991, when it was devalued by around 12 percent and then re-linked to the Ecu.
But strong foreign exchange market speculation forced it further down in value, and it has since been left to float freely.
Finland's five-party coalition government, which is determined to be among the first countries to join a single currency, is responsible for the key decision on whether to seek a markka-ERM link.
Finance Minister Sauli Niinisto said on October 9 it seemed likely that belonging to ERM was an unconditional criterion for joining the third stage of EMU.
"The fact that the currency has been stable is hardly enough, but the general opinion ... is that ERM is a system which one must join," he said.
The EU monetary committee is made up of national treasury and central bank officials. The markka was trading at 2.986 against the German mark at close of market business on Friday.
